text:
Raskolnikov barely reacted as Pyotr Petrovitch stood up. 

“Must’ve been one of her customers who killed her,” Zossimov said confidently. 

“Definitely,” Razumihin agreed. “Porfiry isn’t sharing his thoughts, but he’s looking into everyone who left stuff with her.” 

“Looking into them?” Raskolnikov asked, a bit surprised. 

“Yeah. What’s the big deal?” 

“Nothing.” 

“How’s he getting their names?” Zossimov wondered. 

“Koch gave some, others are on the pledge wrappers, and some just came forward.” 

“It had to be a slick criminal! So bold! So cool!” 

“Not really!” Razumihin jumped in. “That’s what’s misleading. I think he’s not slick or experienced. This was probably his first crime! The idea that it was planned out doesn’t add up. If he was inexperienced, luck is what saved him. He probably didn’t see the obstacles coming! How did he even pull it off? He grabbed some jewels worth ten or twenty roubles, stuffed his pockets, rummaged through the old lady’s stuff—and they found fifteen hundred roubles in cash and notes!” 💰

**PAGE SUMMARY:** the old pawnbroker's possession, indicating the murder was likely committed by an inexperienced individual rather than a cunning criminal.
